ME 495.course_description: Outlet for experimental and other topics which may be of current interest. Crosslisted with ME 695. Credit at the 600-level requires additional work.

ME 497.course_description: Synthesis course to involve students in the design process. Project proposal and design definition.

ME 498.course_description: Synthesis course to involve students in the design process. Analysis, design completion, and presentation.

MGT 301.course_name: Principles of Management and Organizational Behavior
MGT 301.course_description: This course discusses fundamentals and principles of management, including planning, decision making and problem solving, strategic management, structure and design, leadership, control, oral and written communication, and ethics and social responsibility.

MGT 302.course_description: Shows what is involved in forming, operating, and/or owning a small business. For those who work in a small business or want to start a small business.

MGT 304.course_description: Students map out product ideas by describing nine core components on a business model canvas. Students validate models by talking to customers, suppliers, and key partners. Students iterate through the customer development process until they have convincing proof of a viable business model. Benefits students from a variety of backgrounds.

MGT 305.course_description: Internationally recognized course in partnership with NxLeveL and the Nevada Small Business Development Center for students who want to start and grow businesses. NxLeveL certified instructors cover entrepreneurial assessment, research, organization, marketing, financial planning, cash flow, and raising capital. Students will develop comprehensive business plans.

MGT 367.course_description: Objectives, functions, organization, and philosophy of personnel relations. Special emphasis on employment, training, and labor relations.

MGT 371.course_description: This course focuses on the skills of effective leaders and managers with an emphasis on: (1) leadership emergence in work settings; (2) how to lead and manage others effectively; and (3) leadership challenges in the contemporary business landscape such as the intersection of leadership with ethics.

MGT 413.course_description: This course is focused on private equity. In conjunction with the Rebel Venture Fund (RVF), students will identify and screen investment opportunities, interact with existing portfolio companies, and make investment recommendations to the RVF management board.

MGT 415.course_description: Study of the evolution of American business in the context of its changing political and social environment. Analysis of the origins of the American business creed, the concept of social responsibility of business, and the expanding role of the corporation.

MGT 442.course_description: Cutting-edge market-based approaches of dealing with important social problems, the critical process of impact measurement, and the importance of scaling of impact. Students will gain the skills to assess and design improved social entrepreneurial organizations.

MGT 450.course_description: Simulation and modeling. Monte Carlo techniques. Generation of random and stochastic variables; verification of simulation models; design of simulation experiments.

MGT 465.course_description: Systematic discussion of the major labor problems confronting society. Problems relating to management and union, industrial conflicts, collective bargaining, and legal environment considered.

MGT 468.course_description: In-depth exposure to both federal and state legislation involving equal employment opportunity, occupational safety and health, and labor-management relations. Information on and experience in developing, organizing, and constructing an Affirmative Action Plan for both the public and private sectors.

MGT 470.course_description: Analysis of manager and worker jobs in private and public organizations and the social, psychological, economic, and legal influences that affect their compensation.

MGT 473.course_description: This course focuses on the skills and methods managers need to manage staffing and development activities in organizations.

MGT 475.course_description: Capstone course in personnel/human resource management with emphasis on current topics and issues in personnel, legal issues, and quantitative computer tools for personnel decision making. Specialized seminar in management geared toward industrial relations management.

MGT 480.course_description: Fulfills the UNLV General Education Milestone Experience Requirement.

MGT 483.course_description: This course is designed to enhance understanding of the negotiation process, and the ability to negotiate deals, dispute settlements and team decisions. The role of third parties in the negotiation process (arbitrators, mediators and managers as third parties) will also be examined.

MGT 486.course_description: Selected topics, readings, and discussion of current issues in quantitative management systems.

MGT 492.course_description: Concepts, theories, and case studies concerning the behavior of people in modern business organizations.

MGT 493.course_description: Advanced analysis of the nature, problems and approaches to, financing, managing, marketing, staffing and operating the entrepreneurial organization through the study of recent, relevant literature and selected cases.

MGT 494.course_description: Analysis of the nature and problems of, and approaches to, management planning, organizing, decision making, and controlling through the study of recent relevant literature and selected cases.

MGT 495.course_description: Applied quantitative analysis using case studies and computer software. Optimization techniques, stochastic modeling, and Expert Systems. Emphasis on the development of effective decision support systems.

MGT 497.course_description: Learn how to create investor quality business plans. Follow a step-by-step process to develop business plan from an opening executive summary to a financial offering.

MIL 101.course_description: Mission of the armed services, introduction to the United States Army, its customs and traditions, the role of the Army Officer, the role of the Non-Commissioned Officers Corps, Organizations of the TOTAL Army (Including the National Guard and Army Reserves). Introductory orienteering, marksmanship, physical fitness and briefing skills.

MIL 101L.course_name: Military Science Lab and Physical Training I
MIL 101L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 101 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on the introduction to military leadership, planning and execution of squad tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MIL 102.course_description: Continuation of the mission of the armed services, introduction to the United States Army, its customs and traditions, the role of the Non-Commissioned Officers Corps, Organizations of the TOTAL Army (Including the National Guard and Army Reserves). Introductory orienteering, marksmanship, physical fitness and briefing skills.

MIL 102L.course_name: Military Science Lab and Physical Training II
MIL 102L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 102 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on the introduction to military leadership, planning and execution of squad tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MIL 201.course_description: Introduction to leadership and management, which develops the basic skills that must be learned in order to perform as an effective leader. Introduction to the Army Leadership Development Program (LDP), the decision-making process, the code of conduct, the Army Operations Order format and its use. Advanced land navigation, physical fitness and briefing skills.

MIL 201L.course_name: Military Science Lab and Physical Training III
MIL 201L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 201 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on military leadership, planning and execution of squad tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MIL 202.course_description: Leadership and management, which develops the basic skills that must be learned in order to perform as an effective leader. Introduction to the Army Leadership Development Program (LDP), the decision-making process, the code of conduct, the Army Operations Order format and its use. Advanced land navigation, physical fitness, and briefing skills.

MIL 202L.course_name: Military Science Lab and Physical Training IV
MIL 202L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 202 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on military leadership, planning and execution of squad tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MIL 250.course_description: A five week course at Fort Knox, KY intended for those who are interested in ROTC but have missed one or more semesters of military science. This course has four phases intended to develop and hone individual and collective skills. The first phases deals with military customs and courtesies, wear of uniforms and drill and ceremony. The second phase deals with adventure training, obstacle course, hand grenades/weapons, water survival etc. The third phase deals with tactics and military leadership, and the final phase combines all elements into a practical exercise. Travel will be paid by the government.

MIL 264.course_description: US Military History focuses on the student’s ability to analyze military leadership and develop awareness of the lineage and heredity between today’s military and the military of the past. Students are provided an examination/evaluation of the Strategic, Operational, and Tactical levels of the US Military during conflict as they relate to the nine principles of war.

MIL 301.course_description: Includes current tactical doctrine as applied to small unit leadership with special emphasis on those leadership skills required for an ROTC cadet to be successful at the Army ROTC Leadership Development and Assessment course.

MIL 301L.course_name: Advanced Military Science Lab and Physical Training I
MIL 301L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 301 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on military leadership, planning and execution of platoon and squad level tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MIL 302.course_description: Continuation of MIL 301. Includes current tactical doctrine as applied to small unit leadership with special emphasis on those leadership skills required for an ROTC cadet to be successful at the Army ROTC Advanced Camp.

MIL 302L.course_name: Advanced Military Science Lab and Physical Training II
MIL 302L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 302 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on military leadership, planning and execution of platoon and squad level tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class

MIL 304.course_description: Directed reading and research in contemporary military issues oriented towards a student’s transition from cadet to commissioned officer.

MIL 350.course_description: This is the US Army ROTC’s capstone training event held at Fort Knox, KY with the purpose of training Cadets to Army standards, develop leadership skills, and to evaluate officer potential. The 31 day course starts with individual training and leads to collective training, building from simple to complex tasks.

MIL 401.course_description: Contemporary military policy and related subjects of topical military interest, military law, the military justice system, courts-martial, personal ethics and the role of the junior officer.

MIL 401L.course_name: Advanced Military Science Lab and  Physical Training III
MIL 401L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 401 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on military leadership, battalion staff planning and training development for the execution of platoon and squad level tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MIL 402.course_description: Continuation of contemporary military policy and related subjects of topical military interest, including military law, the military justice system, courts-martial, personal ethics and the role of the junior officer.

MIL 402L.course_name: Advanced Military Science Lab and Physical Training IV
MIL 402L.course_description: Practicum in those skills taught in conjunction with classroom instruction given during the MIL 402 Lecture. Hands-on lab focusing on military leadership, battalion staff planning and training development for the execution of platoon and squad level tactics, movement formations, and land navigation. Lab required every semester in conjunction with the appropriate military science class.

MKT 225.course_name: Contemporary Analysis of the Hispanic Experience in Business

MKT 301.course_description: Planning and executing the conception, pricing, promotion, and distribution of ideas, goods, and services to create exchanges that satisfy individual and organizational objectives. Focuses on concepts and frameworks informing strategic, tactical, and ethical marketing decisions. Features modules on segmentation, positioning, the 4 Ps, ethics/social responsibility, and communication of marketing proposals.

MKT 312.course_description: Individual differences, social and cultural factors, and situational variables that impact on attitude formation and change, learning, decision making, and behavior of consumers. Emphasis on the use of this information to develop marketing programs.

MKT 380.course_name: Managing Customer Experiences in the Digital World
MKT 380.course_description: Theory and practice of marketing in the digital world. Focuses on the role of digital technologies in a marketing strategy and the shaping of customer experiences in the digital world using online and mobile platforms, tactics, and tools. Course requires formulation of an original digital marketing strategy.

MKT 400.course_description: Methodology of research. Focuses on topics such as research design, sample design, questionnaire construction, field procedures, data analysis, and report preparation. Involves practical experience in marketing research.

MKT 422.course_description: The communication process as it relates to the promotional mix, including both traditional and non-traditional media. Theories and applications pertaining to all strategically managed areas of marketing communications are covered.

MKT 425.course_name: Global Consumer Behavior and The Consumer Experience

MKT 427.course_description: Study of the components of a successful advertising campaign. Students undertake preliminary preparations for an actual ad campaign.

MKT 435.course_name: Marketing to Hispanics, in the US and Globally

MKT 441.course_description: Structure of institutions in the channel of distribution, including retailers, wholesalers, and agent middlemen. Organization and appraisal of movement and storage of raw materials, work-in-process, and finished goods, middleman functions, including inventory and price policies, trade sales promotion, franchising, and other vertical marketing systems.

MKT 442.course_description: Creating and marketing global retailing experiences. Focuses on retailing functions and strategies for value-driven, profitable in-store and digital consumer shopping experiences.  Course features coverage of emerging issues and trends, field visits, guest speakers, and formulation of an original customer retailing experience using marketing variables.

MKT 448.course_name: Projects, Competitions and Cases in Marketing Research
MKT 448.course_description: Data driven marketing strategies and decision making based on combining all aspects of the research process. Integration of results from qualitative and quantitative exploratory, descriptive, and causal primary and secondary research.

MKT 450.course_name: Competitive Strategies for Product and Price Management
MKT 450.course_description: Competitive analysis and planning techniques for product and price management. Focus on defining the competition, analyzing the competition’s posture, and positioning, developing competitive strategies and tactics, market opportunity analysis, segmentation, competitive analysis, product positioning, brand equity management, setting and managing price.

MKT 455.course_description: Marketing problems and strategies specific to service industries. Differences in the marketing of intangibles and services. Emphasis on services in general, rather than any particular industry. Concepts applied to such service industries as health care, the professions, the arts, banking, financial services, advertising and communications, and consulting.

MKT 456.course_description: Planning and executing the conception, pricing, promotion, and distribution of ideas, goods, and services to create exchanges that satisfy individual and organizational objectives. Focuses on concepts and frameworks informing strategic, tactical, and ethical marketing decisions. Features modules on segmentation, positioning, the 4 Ps, ethics/social responsibility, and communication of marketing proposals.

MKT 464.course_name: Professional Sales Negotiations Strategies and Tactics
MKT 464.course_description: The theory, processes, and practices of sales negotiation, relationship building and conflict resolution. Builds on the concepts learned in the Marketing Management course. Develops an understanding of the marketing theories, strategies, and tactics of effective sales negotiation, conflict resolution, and relationship management.

MKT 465.course_description: Management of the sales force strategies for marketing products and services. Topics include the strategic role of the sales function; the sales process; relationship and sales channel strategies; the design, development, direction, and evaluation of the sales organization; and ethical and global dimensions.

MKT 468.course_description: Theory, concepts, and skills associated with using databases to enhance marketing programs and build strong relationships with customers.

MKT 470.course_description: Principles and applications of direct marketing, frequency marketing programs, relationship marketing, and integrated marketing. Focus on database management, selection of products and services, and developing the offer.

MKT 471.course_description: Identification, analysis, assessment and use of data relevant to marketing strategy decision making. Focus is on turning data into information and information into data driven marketing strategies and on ethical and technical issues related to data privacy. Course requires an original project that applies analytics to a marketing decision situation.

MKT 472.course_description: Marketing planning skills. Includes practice of developing marketing plans and the use of marketing technology and models in the marketing planning process.

MKT 473.course_description: Provide a thorough grounding in industrial or business-to-business marketing. While many of the concepts are similar to those used in consumer marketing, there are significant differences. This course will explore both the similarities and the differences.

MKT 474.course_description: Theory and application relevant to marketing sports experiences. Focuses on marketing strategy and tactics that maximize experiential value of sports to consumers, corporate sponsors, and team franchise equity. Course requires formulation of an original experiential oriented sports marketing plan.

MKT 475.course_description: Framework for marketing of entertainment experiences. Focuses on the experitential nature of entertainment products, marketing issues and trends in entertainment industries including television, film, music, gaming, and theater, and marketing strategy and tactics for entertainment products. Course requires formulation of a marketing strategy for an entertainment product.

MKT 483.course_description: Supervised on-site practical, professional learning experience in marketing.

MKT 492.course_description: Selected topics, readings, and discussion of current marketing issues.

MKT 494.course_description: Basic understanding of developing, managing and enhancing experiential goods and services. Topics include: understanding and measuring the experience, design issues, management issues, wearout, and developing memorable experiences.

MKT 495.course_description: Marketing analysis and decision making. Integrates knowledge acquired in other courses in marketing and related areas. Extensive use of cases and/or computer simulations.

MUS 100.course_description: Attendance at least ten on-campus concerts and/or recitals as a member of the audience.

MUS 101.course_description: Introduction to music reading. Study of notation, rhythm, scales, intervals, and chords with emphasis on ear training. Recommended for elementary education majors and anyone interested in learning to sing or play an instrument.

MUS 102.course_description: Review course designed for music majors whose background in music theory is not sufficient for admittance into MUS 201. Not applicable to degree with a major in music. Rudimentary harmony, notation, scales, intervals, chords, part writing. Entry level sight-singing and ear training. Pass with C- at least or 70%.

MUS 103.course_description: Class instruction in the fundamentals of correct breathing, tone production, and diction. Designed for non-music majors with little or no previous voice training.

MUS 104.course_description: Class instruction for students with previous vocal training to apply techniques of singing and acquire additional repertoire in environment suitable for performance.

MUS 105R.course_description: Fundamentals of tone production, breath control, diction and practical techniques involved in reading and interpreting songs.

MUS 107.course_description: Beginning guitar. Basic guitar technique. Recommended for non-music majors and elementary school teachers.

MUS 108.course_description: Beginning guitar. Basic guitar technique. Recommended for non-music majors and elementary school teachers.

MUS 109.course_description: Beginning piano for music majors only. Continued instruction in piano for music majors.

MUS 110.course_description: Continued instruction in piano for music majors.

MUS 111.course_description: Beginning piano. Basic piano technique. Recommended for non-music majors and elementary school teachers.

MUS 113.course_description: Theoretical and practical approach to basic techniques and principles of music composition.

MUS 115.course_description: Basic skills in musicianship, vocal production, breath support, and use of singing voice. Prepares students for private study and musical theatre stage.

MUS 121.course_description: Introduction to the music literatures and cultures of Europe and the Americas, along with other world regions. The course emphasizes the development of listening, analytical, critical, and interpretative skills. Ability to read music is not required.

MUS 125.course_description: Esthetics and sociology of rock from its origins in rhythm and blues to the rise of Elvis Presley and rockabilly; Chuck Berry and teen-age rock; Bob Dylan and protest rock; the Beatles and Rolling Stones; psychedelic rock; and soul.

MUS 127.course_description: Surveys the world’s music. Develops better music listening skills by exposure to a wide variety of live performances. Popular, jazz, folk, classical, Indian, African, Native American, and Latin American musical styles explored. Recommended for elementary education majors and anyone interested in musical expressions of world culture.

MUS 129.course_description: Opera appreciation course, focusing on the dramatic aspects of opera from Monteverdi to Andrew Lloyd Webber. Emphasis on sex and violence and its significance in the operatic medium.

MUS 130.course_description: Original cast albums from Show Boat to A Chorus Line serves as the basis of analysis of composers from Jerome Kern, Rodgers & Hart, and Cole Porter to Stephen Sondheim, Marvin Hamlisch, and Andrew Lloyd Webber.

MUS 131.course_description: Development of a listening repertoire that will serve as a basis for music history studies.

MUS 133.course_description: History of the Beatles from their beginning in Liverpool, England, to their unequaled world popularity. Features a mixture of videos, including the Beatles Anthology series, “A Hard Days Night,” “Help!,” “Yellow Submarine,” “Magical Mystery Tour,” and much more. Covers every important phase of the world’s most successful and beloved rock band.

MUS 134.course_description: Study of jazz literature for the layperson from the early 1900s to the present, with emphasis on differentiating the various styles of jazz playing.

KIN 493.course_description: Experience applying theoretical concepts introduced in exercise physiology. Introduction to the scientific method and research writing.

KIN 494.course_description: Experience applying theoretical concepts in kinesiology. Introduction to the scientific method and research writing.

KIN 495.course_description: Pharmacological aspects of sports medicine. Basic drugs used to treat a variety of sports-related injuries and problems. Pathophysiology of athletic injury. Special topics in sports medicine discussed.

KIN 496.course_description: The study of gross human anatomy as it applies to clinical situations. Materials to be covered include: neuromusculoskeletal structures of the trunk and extremities. Emphasis will be placed on osteology, muscles’ function, innervation, and vascular supply, and using advanced knowledge of these structures to introduce clinical reasoning skills.

KIN 497.course_description: Practicum for upper-division students to experience working in a traditional or non-traditional athletic training setting in the community.

KIN 498.course_description: Designed to prepare students for the BOC certification exam, graduate school application, and full time employment. Professional and ethical conduct will be discussed.

KIN 499.course_description: Independent study of a selected topic in kinesiology and nutrition sciences.

LAND 240.course_description: Introductory examination of the science of horticulture as it applies to landscape architecture.

LAND 242.course_description: Introduces basic design of irrigation, construction and maintenance of irrigation. Sizing of components calculated and available products introduced.

LAND 255.course_description: The history of designed landscapes from ancient times to today. Environmental, social and cultural factors which influence human made landscapes.

LAND 258.course_description: Identification, distribution, growth, characteristics, adaptation, and usage of xeric plants. Emphasizes bedding plants, shrubs and trees.

LAND 280.course_description: Students continue their inquiry into fundamentals of design principles. Emphasis will be placed on the interconnection between concepts and applications using various programmatic, topological, and technological themes.

LAND 306.course_description: A collaborative experience where students work intensively during a short period of time with a local community to solve their problems by generating and presenting multiple design solutions.

LAND 330.course_description: Explanation of the effects of climate on thermal comfort. Comprehensive coverage of basic climatic design principles. Emphasizes integrating available solar and renewable energies in design.

LAND 340.course_description: An introduction to the identification, distribution, growth, characteristics, adaptation, and usage of plant materials appropriate for arid environments.

LAND 342.course_description: Examines the elements, principles and theories of planting and irrigation design in landscape architecture. An emphasis will be placed on regionally appropriate techniques and strategies.

LAND 343.course_description: An introduction to basic site surveying techniques and site grading principles. Emphasis will be placed on contour manipulation as an interface between natural and man-made topographical conditions.

LAND 384.course_description: Examines the fundamental principles and theories of site analysis, site programming, and site design in landscape architecture.

LAND 386.course_description: Landscape architectural design applications of large-scale site analysis, land use planning, and ecosystem management issued.

LAND 442.course_name: Materials and Methods for Landscape Architecture
LAND 442.course_description: Examines the basic materials and methods used in landscape architecture site construction with an emphasis on sustainable materials and construction practices.

LAND 443.course_description: Lecture course addressing the design and calculations of stormwater management systems, best management practices, surface and subsurface drainage systems, basic hydrology, horizontal and vertical layout, specifications of planting plans, demolition and tree preservation plans, specifications, and erosion and sediment control design and practices.

LAND 455.course_description: Investigates the vernacular landscape evolving from decisions made in manipulating physical and social environments. Examines various landscape types, including agricultural, residential, strip development, landfill, industrial, transportation corridors, landmarks, and centers. Emphasizes wayfinding, implied symbolism, and meaning in the landscape.

LAND 467.course_name: Geographic Information Systems for Landscape Architecture
LAND 467.course_description: Explores the fundamental uses of Geographic Information Systems in landscape architecture.

LAND 484.course_description: Application of the elements, principles and theories of performance-based sustainable design in landscape architecture.

LAND 486.course_description: Studio course focused on the successful completion of a capstone design project. An emphasis will be placed on the integration of design theory, principles, and applications at a level that demonstrates a synthesized understanding of research and design methodologies in landscape architecture.

LAND 491.course_description: Issues of professional practice, including legal requirements, ethics, management structures, malpractice claims, value engineering, contracts, and the professional job market.

LAND 493.course_description: Independent study of a selected landscape architecture topic.

LAND 495.course_description: Experimental and other topics which may be of current interest in landscape architecture.

LAND 499.course_name: Sustainable Design for the 21st Century City
LAND 499.course_description: An integrative approach to human and natural systems in urban areas. Ecological principles, sustainable design, and human-ecosystem interaction will be examined at a variety of scales. Sustainable design concepts will be linked to design and planning principles.

LAS 100.course_description: This course is designed to introduce students to the field of Latina/o Studies through the fields of history, sociology, political science, literature and education. Students will use multidisciplinary approaches to this field of study and integrate the various fields to understand the complexity of researching this dynamic population.

LAS 101.course_description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the culture, history, and political economy of contemporary Latin America. Examines the history of colonialism and independence, values and social structures, political institutions, and economic relations in ‘the region.

LAS 227.course_name: Introduction to Latin American History and Culture I

LAS 228.course_name: Introduction to Latin American History and Culture II

LAS 405N.course_name: Regional and International Relations of Latin America and the Caribbean

LAS 440E.course_name: Archaeology of Mexico and Central America

LAS 499.course_description: Program of independent reading and research, to be selected in consultation with an instructor before registration, and with the approval of the Latin American Studies Program Chair.

LAT 113.course_description: First-year Latin grammar, reading, and vocabulary building.

LAT 114.course_description: First-year Latin grammar, reading, and vocabulary building.

LAT 213.course_description: Intermediate Latin grammar, reading, and vocabulary expansion.

LAT 214.course_description: Intermediate Latin grammar, reading, and vocabulary expansion.

LAT 331.course_description: Selected masterpieces of Latin literature in English translation.

LAW 432.course_description: Discusses constitutional right to privacy, the four privacy torts, contrast between right of privacy and right against defamation, and right of publicity.

LCE 230.course_description: Encourage analyzing of responsibilities and commitment in the context of leadership. An understanding leadership as a process, rather than a position will be developed and ways this varies from traditional leadership theories. Theories, concepts, and skills will be explored and will be asked to apply this knowledge to their own leadership philosophy.

LCE 231.course_description: A survey of fundamental leadership theory and skills. Students will apply knowledge gained from the course directly to their roles as leaders on and off campus.

LCE 381.course_description: Learning how to leading in a dynamic 21st century world means thinking broadly about diversity for leadership positions in a global world. Focuses on improving personal leadership skills and emphasizing the importance of leading consistently with the highest ethical principles and values.

LCE 382.course_description: Leading in a dynamic 21st century world requires that leaders think broadly about issues related to social justice. Focuses on improving personal leadership skills and emphasize the importance of leading with the highest ethical principles and values.

LCE 385.course_name: Conflict and the Role of Leadership
LCE 385.course_description: Introduction of concepts, theory and practice of the role of leader in conflict resolution, decreasing community conflict and understanding interpersonal conflict and the applications of these to historical and current leadership situations, specifically for the development of skills in mediation and a personal style of conflict resolution.

LCE 386.course_description: Develop core competencies in designing and facilitating structured group workshops. Students will explore and experience all aspects of a group workshop including conception of an idea through facilitation and evaluation. Multiple learning methods will be used including readings and lectures, however a large emphasis will be placed on experimental learning.

LCE 387.course_description: Explore and develop concepts of effective leadership as they relate to personal development. An experiential learning climate which includes a strong base knowledge of leadership theory including the role of values, ethics, communication, group dynamics, and diversity.

LCE 388.course_description: Students enrolled in this internship course will further develop their knowledge and skills in leadership through practical experiences. It requires students to complete 100 (3 credits) clock hours of work onsite, either at UNLV or at an approved organization or community agency.

LDE 201.course_description: Introduction to leadership theories, concepts, and skills. Examination of the evolution of leadership theory; exploration of a personal leadership philosophy; understanding leadership as a process rather than a position; and analyzing the interaction of identity with leadership practice.

LDE 202.course_description: Introduction to ethical decision-making and ethical leadership.  Exploration of contemporary issues in organizations, communities, and society and the analysis of practices that encourage ethical behavior.

LDE 311.course_description: Critical examination of the leadership studies field and exploration of the role that identity plays in defining, framing, studying, and enacting leadership. Exploration of identity, socialization, critical theory, critical race theory, and intersectionality. Links personal identities and leadership practice, develops the ability to critically consume and re-author leadership literature.

LDE 312.course_description: Examines leadership as a relational process. Critical analysis of authentic leadership, positive psychology, conflict, mediation, and team dynamics. Explores how personal relationships shapes the leadership process, values different talents that team members contribute to the group process, and increases skill in navigating conflict.

LDE 313.course_description: Examines how the leadership process can transform systemic social issues. Exploration of social change, activism, and advocating against social injustice; critical exploration of cultural identities; interrogation of systems of power, privilege, and oppression; and commitment to social justice.

LDE 314.course_description: Considers the ways in which leadership theory and practice are changing in response to an increasingly globalized context. Examination of power, diversity, and systems in a variety of social institutions including sustainability, politics, media, the labor market, and security and conflict in a global environment.

LIN 101.course_description: Study of natural and artificial languages as expressions of cognition and culture. Topics include language structure and origins, cognitive models, categorization, schemas, thinking for speaking, spatial language, parallel processing, language modules, and neural networks. Students analyze samples of natural language and reconstruct their underlying cognitive models.

MATH 115.course_description: Study of some elementary and elegant examples displaying mathematics as a medium for artistic expression and aesthetic appreciation. Intended for students with limited mathematical background, but not preparation for college algebra or the precalculus mathematics sequence. Does not satisfy the general education core mathematics requirement.

MATH 120.course_description: Real numbers; consumer mathematics; variation; functions, relations, and graphs; geometry of measurement; probability and statistics; sets and logic. Broad in scope course, emphasizes applications.

MATH 120E.course_description: Real numbers; consumer mathematics; variation; functions, relations, and graphs; geometry of measurement; probability and statistics; sets and logic. Broad in scope course, emphasizes applications. Note: This is a 3+2 credit course. 3 of 5 credits counts as MATH 120 and towards graduation; the two corequisite credits does not count toward the total needed for graduation.

MATH 121.course_name: Mathematical Topics and Applications Provided in a Real World Context
MATH 121.course_description: Introduction to mathematical concepts such as: logic and analytic thinking, related rates, functions and relations, graphs and representations, properties of numbers, set theory, and consumer mathematics. Students will be exposed to topics within the context of practical applications. Technology will be incorporated.

MATH 122.course_name: Number Concepts for Elementary School Teachers
MATH 122.course_description: Mathematics needed by those teaching the new-content curriculum at the elementary school level, emphasis on number concepts. MATH 122 does not satisfy the general education core mathematics requirement.

MATH 123.course_name: Statistical and Geometrical Concepts for Elementary School Teachers
MATH 123.course_description: Mathematics needed by those teaching the new-content curriculum at the elementary school level, emphasizing concepts in statistics and geometry.

MATH 124.course_description: Equations and inequalities; relations and functions; linear, quadratic, polynomial, exponential, and logarithm functions; systems of linear equations and inequalities; matrices; sequences and series; binomial theorem.

MATH 124E.course_description: Equations and inequalities; relations and functions; linear, quadratic, polynomial, exponential, and logarithm functions; systems of linear equations and inequalities; matrices; sequences and series; binomial theorem. This is a 3+2 credit course. Only 3 of 5 credits counts as MATH 124 and towards graduation; the two corequisite credits does not count toward the total needed for graduation.

MATH 126.course_description: Topics include fundamentals of algebra, functions and graphs, polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions, and systems of linear equations.

MATH 126E.course_description: Topics include fundamentals of algebra, functions and graphs, polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions, and systems of linear equations. This is a 3+2 credit course. Only 3 of 5 credits are counted for MATH 126 and toward graduation; the two corequisite credits are not counted toward the total needed for graduation.

MATH 127.course_description: Topics include circular functions, trigonometric identities and equations, conic sections, complex numbers, and discrete algebra.

MATH 128.course_description: Relations, functions, and their graphs; polynomial, rational, exponential, logarithm, and trigonometric functions; analytic trigonometry; systems of equations and inequalities; conics; mathematical induction; sequences and series. A combination of

MATH 132.course_description: Logic, sets, probability, matrices, and linear programming, and their application to the analysis of business and social science problems.

MATH 170.course_description: Mathematical study of interest, annuities, sinking funds, depreciation, amortization, and other topics related to business problems.

MATH 176.course_name: Introductory Calculus for Business and Social Sciences
MATH 176.course_description: Techniques of calculus, with applications to the analysis of business and social science problems. Topics include functions of one and several variables, differentiation and partial differentiation, integration, and optimization.

MATH 181.course_description: Differentiation and integration of algebraic and transcendental functions, with applications.

MATH 182.course_description: Further applications and techniques of integration including integration by parts, sequences and series, polynomial approximations.

MATH 213.course_description: Analyzing and solving standard and non-standard problems using a variety of different problem-solving techniques, tools, and technology. Emphasizes different approaches to solving problems and complete oral and/or written explanations of how to solve the problems.

MATH 214.course_description: Study of one- two- and three-dimensional geometry, including figures, properties, and transformations, using classical and analytical methods. Emphasis on developing an appreciation for the widespread use of geometry and using geometry to solve problems.

MATH 251.course_description: Topics include set operations, Cartesian product, relations and functions, equivalence relation, graphs and digraphs, propositional calculus, truth tables, mathematical induction, elementary combinatorics with applications.

MATH 271.course_description: Review of sets, counting, finite and countable probability spaces, random variables and distribution functions, statistical quantities, limit theorems, applications.

MATH 283.course_description: Vectors; differentiation and integration of vector valued functions; multivariable calculus; partial derivatives; multiple integrals and applications; line, surface and volume integrals; Green’s theorem; divergence theorem; and Stoke’s theorem.

MATH 303.course_name: Introduction to Proofs in Metric Spaces and Analysis
MATH 303.course_description: Proofs are presented in context of the following topics at the introductory level: logic, set theory, topology of metric spaces, sequences and functions, limits and continuity.

MATH 313.course_description: Topics include sets, functions, relations, propositional logic, induction, elementary combinatorics, and elementary graph theory.

MUS 135.course_description: The history of popular music in all its forms in the United States from 1840, progressing chronologically to the present day.

MUS 137.course_description: Examination of the British Invasion of the early 1960s taught from an ethnomusicological standpoint. Taught by text, lecture, and video. Examines thirty different British Invasion groups.

MUS 139.course_description: Provides music and non-music majors with a basic understanding of how music and computers correlate. Sound/data management, multimedia capabilities, CD and DVD reproduction, music notation, MIDI, basic recording and editing.

MUS 139E.course_description: Provides an understanding of how to develop interactive and engaging experiences for students in the modern music classroom. Topics include current available technologies for music education, multimedia capabilities, music and video processing, podcasting,  basic recording, and editing. Required: tablet or computer with ability to run music apps; basic computer skills.

MUS 141A.course_description: Introduction to commercial music theory and arranging. Study of notation, rhythm, scales, intervals, and chords with emphasis on music arranging. This course is designed for students working toward the Commercial Music Performance certificates. Others may take the course with instructor approval.

MUS 141B.course_description: Expanding your knowledge and application of commercial music theory and arranging. Intermediate study of notation, rhythm, scales, intervals, and chords with emphasis on music arranging. This course is designed for students working toward the Commercial Music Performance certificate 2. or, students that have successfully completed MUS 141A.

MUS 143.course_description: Fundamentals of Italian, German, and French phonetics and diction as applied to singing.

MUS 144.course_description: Advanced fundamentals of Italian, German, and French phonetics and diction as applied to singing.

MUS 167.course_description: A graduation requirement of all music majors covering all skills considered necessary for success in all music careers. Functional keyboard skills combined with the application of music theory principles at the piano.

MUS 169.course_description: Learn techniques associated with the art of playing world percussion. Specific ethnic instruments from the Middle East, Far East, Africa and South America are studied in context of historical, social and performance practices.​

MUS 173.course_description: Practical on-stage experience in musical theatre productions. May be repeated to a maximum of eight credits.

MUS 181.course_description: Survey about music merchandising, artistic management, record and publishing companies, artists’ unions, ASCAP and BMI, agents, record production, song writing and copyright registration. Includes how to make a demo tape, promote a concert, and choose a personal manager.

MUS 191A.course_description: Beginning and Intermediate Reed Making skills for oboe players.

MUS 191B.course_description: Applied basic to intermediate reed-making for double reed music majors.

MUS 192A.course_description: Advanced Reed Making for oboe players.

MUS 192B.course_name: Advanced Reedmaking for Double Reed Instruments (bassoon)
MUS 192B.course_description: Applied basic to intermediate reed-making for double reed music majors.

MUS 201.course_description: Basic study of diatonic harmony and voice leading, as well as the aural and sight-singing skills required for the understanding and practice of these subjects.

MUS 202.course_description: Study of aspects of intermediate tonal harmony and voice leading, as well as the aural and sight-singing skills required for the understanding and practice of these subjects.

MUS 202F.course_description: Sight-singing and Ear Training. Ear training and sight-singing, as related to the harmonic materials of MUS 202E .

MUS 209.course_description: Continued instruction in piano for music majors.

MUS 210.course_description: Continued instruction in piano for music majors.

MUS 215.course_description: Practical course in composing pop music. Analysis of hit songs and discussion of songs written by the class. Each student composes ten melodies to given lyrics.

MUS 217.course_description: Historical and philosophical basis for film scores.

MUS 230.course_description: Provides a more detailed look into the relationship between music production and computers. Topics include digital signal processing (DSP), software synthesis, Plug-In architectures, computer audio hardware and the essential components of the digital audio workstation (DAW).

MUS 231.course_description: Concepts of sound for recording, including basics of sound wave propagation, microphones, formats for sound storage, mixers, etc. This is the entry level course for the recording program and is either recommended or required for every course offered. Special fee charged.

MUS 232.course_description: Intermediate course in multi-track recording techniques including discussions on session procedures, production techniques, tracking and overdubbing methods, and general equipment operation.

MUS 235.course_description: Introduction to computerized methods of music notation. Students use Finale tm to produce parts and scores according to professional standards in all fields of music.

MUS 239.course_description: Explores the complete theory and application of hard disk recording systems, particularly Pro Tools, from setup to mastering. Students have hands-on experience while learning concepts and techniques for proper functioning of MIDI, digital audio, I/O, plug-ins, etc.

MUS 249.course_description: This course is designed for students with any level of mariachi performance experience. Students will receive instruction on the violin, trumpet, vihuela, guitar, guitarron, and harp. A thorough knowledge of basic musical concepts is necessary for this course.

MUS 250.course_description: This course is designed for students with any level of mariachi performance experience. Students will receive instruction on the different styles of mariachi music and the nuances inherent in each style.

MUS 252.course_description: Examination of jazz & commercial harmonic practices, including chord progressions, extensions, and substitutions, scales, reharmonization, and ear training exercises.

MUS 257.course_description: Beginning jazz piano course for music majors.

MUS 258.course_description: Study and application of the techniques involved in jazz & commercial improvisation as related to all styles of the jazz & commercial music idiom.

MUS 259.course_description: Development of skills singing in the interpretive and improvisational jazz styles.

MUS 271.course_description: Introduction to the principles, philosophy, and trends of music education in the public schools. Preparatory experience for other professional courses in music education. Observation of 15 hours of music instruction at all levels required and participation in the university classroom.

MUS 273.course_description: Rehearsal and performance laboratory for music education students.

MUS 303.course_description: Study of advanced tonal and post-tonal music and the aural and sight-singing skills required for the understanding and practice of these subjects.

MUS 304.course_description: Study of aspects of advanced tonal and post-tonal harmony and voice leading, as well as the aural and sight-singing skills required for the understanding and practice of these subjects.

MUS 313.course_description: Techniques and principles of music composition. Each level may be repeated to a maximum of four credits. Prerequisites: Ability to read music and some knowledge of an instrument, and consent of instructor. 2 credits.

MUS 319.course_description: Production of digital multimedia, including assembly of DVD and CD projects for students representing their body of work, how to set up a website, streaming audio and video for the web, and more.

MUS 320.course_description: Learn the basics of a large, automated console, including operation, wiring, practicality, and maintenance. Students record several sessions of varying complexity and then compile their final mixes on the Euphonix CS3000 with full utilization of plug-ins, dynamics, and automation with recall.

MUS 331.course_description: Survey of literature designed for the piano major. Includes music from Couperin through Liszt, focusing on J.S. Bach, Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven, Schubert, and Schumann. Study of early keyboard instruments, their properties, and playing techniques.

MUS 332.course_description: Survey of literature designed for the piano major. Focuses on music of Chopin, Brahms, Bartok, Prokofiev, and avant-garde composers and their techniques.

MUS 341.course_description: Historical survey of significant musical artists and works from the Middle Ages to about 1750, studied in the context of pertinent compositional, performance, cultural, and societal issues.

MUS 342.course_description: Historical survey of significant musical artists and works from about 1750 to 1900, studied in the context of pertinent compositional, performance, cultural, and societal issues.

MUS 343.course_description: Historical survey of significant musical artists and works from about 1900 to the present, studied in the context of pertinent compositional, performance, cultural, and societal issues.

MUS 345.course_name: Jazz and Commercial Music History I
MUS 345.course_description: Survey of the history of jazz and commercial music from its origins through early jazz, the swing era and bebop.

MUS 346.course_description: Continuation of Jazz & Commercial History I from the bebop era to the present.

MUS 348.course_description: Exploration of the evolution of American musical forms. Emphasis placed on understanding the various cultural and ethnic influences on music in America and how they fused to create distinctly American genres such as jazz, musical theater, American folk, pop, and aleatoric music.

MUS 350.course_name: The Theory and Application of Microphones
MUS 350.course_description: This course will teach the fundamentals of microphone care, choice, placement and techniques for recording. It will also provide an in-depth look at the different types of microphones, their polar patterns and various characteristics. Other aspects such as self-noise, sensitivity and construction will also be covered.

MUS 351.course_description: Evolution of vocal jazz from 1920 through 1960. Combination of lectures and listening. Vocalists include: Louis Armstrong, Bessie Smith, Dinah Washington, Ella Fitzgerald, Sarah Vaughan and others.

MUS 352.course_description: Evolution of vocal jazz from 1960-present. Based on a combination of lectures and listening. Oral presentation and performance of a vocal transcription required. Vocalists include: Sheila Jordan, Carmen McRae, George Benson, Flora Purim, Bobby McFerrin, Take Six, and others.

MUS 357.course_description: In-depth study of the artistic, theoretical, and stylistic techniques of jazz artists through the analysis of their transcribed solos.

MUS 358.course_name: Advanced Jazz and Commercial Music Improvisation
MUS 358.course_description: Continuation of MUS 258, with emphasis on advanced techniques and applications of jazz improvisation.

MUS 359.course_name: Beginning Jazz and Commercial Arranging and Composition
MUS 359.course_description: Emphasis on techniques of arranging and composition for the contemporary jazz orchestra and commercial ensemble.

MUS 360.course_name: Advanced Jazz Vocal Arranging and Composition
MUS 360.course_description: Beginning to intermediate arranging and composition techniques. Career preparation for vocal jazz performers. Topics include: basic tune writing, lead-sheet writing, vocal arrangement with piano trio, two-horn arrangement for vocal with trio.

MUS 362.course_description: Basic principles of conducting and score reading. Students must be members of one of the performance ensembles.

MUS 365.course_description: Intensive study of all orchestral and band instruments, their ranges and characteristics, and the techniques of scoring for small and large groups. Transcriptions from piano scores.

MUS 372.course_description: Develop and refine basic conducting skills for future instrumental conducting experiences through demonstration, discussion, and analysis of appropriate applications. Emphasis is placed on score realization, pedagogy, and rehearsal techniques.

MUS 373.course_description: Develop and refine basic conducting skills for future choral conducting experiences through demonstration, discussion, and analysis of appropriate applications. Emphasis is placed on score realization, pedagogy, and rehearsal techniques.

MUS 374.course_description: Sequential and logical study of the process used when teaching the Orff approach, including imitation, exploration, and creation.

MUS 375.course_description: Instrumental techniques and problems of teaching music in junior and senior high schools.

MUS 376.course_description: Vocal techniques and problems of teaching music in junior and senior high schools.

MUS 378.course_description: Techniques for teaching general music, to include presenting rote and note songs, teaching note reading, singing games, listening, rhythmic expression, movement, creativity and simple rhythm and pitched percussion instruments.

MUS 385.course_description: Techniques of teaching string instruments with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 385A.course_description: Techniques of teaching violin and viola, with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 385B.course_description: Techniques of teaching cello and bass, with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 386.course_description: Techniques of teaching percussion instruments with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 386A.course_description: Techniques of teaching percussion instruments (snare, keyboard, timpani, auxiliary), with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction. Includes practical and written examination.

MUS 386B.course_description: Techniques of teaching percussion instruments (Latin, multiple, marching, drum set), with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction. Includes practical and written examination.

MUS 387.course_description: Techniques of teaching brass instruments with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 387A.course_description: Techniques of teaching high brass instruments (trumpet, cornet, French horn), with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 387B.course_description: Techniques of teaching low brass instruments (trombone, baritone/euphonium, tuba), with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 388.course_description: Techniques of teaching woodwind instruments with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 388A.course_description: Techniques of teaching woodwind instruments (single reed/flute), with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 388B.course_description: Techniques of teaching woodwind instruments (double reeds), with emphasis on performance, pedagogy, and group instruction.

MUS 389.course_description: Hands-on study of playing techniques and pedagogical approaches to instruments found within the rhythm section of a jazz band.

MUS 391.course_description: A practical and historical survey of marching band techniques and movements. Direct observation and student projects explore and reinforce necessary skills.

MUS 398.course_description: Presentation of a half recital (minimum of 20 minutes actual playing time).

MUS 399.course_description: Presentation of a half recital (minimum of 20 minutes actual playing time).

MUS 401.course_description: Analysis of polyphonic practices including sixteenth-, eighteenth-, and twentieth-century styles.

MUS 404E.course_description: Study of some of the most influential materials and techniques from the music of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.

MUS 404F.course_description: Advanced Sight-singing and Ear Training. Ear training and sight-singing related to the harmonic materials of

MUS 405.course_description: Practical studies in music theory and ear training through keyboard exercises. Intermediate piano skills required.

MUS 408.course_description: Study of form (binary, ternary, rondo, sonata, concerto, fugue, open forms, etc.) as found in music from the Middle Ages to the most recent.

MUS 414.course_description: Survey of choral literature and stylistic practices from the Renaissance through the twentieth century.

MUS 415.course_description: A study of band and orchestra literature for public school ensembles, students will listen, study scores, and discuss instructional techniques and repertoire.

MUS 417.course_description: Introduction to the basic problems involved in the teaching of voice. Study of tone production, breathing, diction, interpretation and style. Does not fulfill requirements for elementary or secondary school vocal methods.

MUS 418.course_description: Survey of beginning piano methods. Organization of a private studio: policies and marketing. Teaching observations and directed teaching individual and class setting required.

MUS 419.course_description: Study and practice in the use of concepts of instrumental music pedagogy. Students complete a series of assignments including reading, library research, observation, and studio teaching.

MUS 426.course_description: Survey of representative solo song literature, with emphasis on Italian, French, and German art songs.

MUS 429.course_description: Study of German art song from 1700 to the present. Emphasis on style and interpretation, including study of the musical and historical contexts and their effect on poetry and art-song literature.

MUS 430.course_description: Study of French mélodie from 1800 to the present. Emphasis on style and interpretation, including the study of the musical and historical contexts and their effect on poetry and art-song literature.

MUS 433.course_description: Advanced Hard Disk recording techniques on the Pro Tools HD Systems, including concepts in Surround Sound. Topics include HUI control surface, multi-channel monitoring and mix-down, and software plug-ins. Geared toward audio engineering in the DVD/Audio, Film and Multimedia fields.

MUS 434.course_description: This 3 credit Course will teach the advanced techniques of Audio Mastering. Frequency Analysis and playback compatibility will be covered in detail along with the necessary tools used to create final masters for the various formats, in addition to a detailed study of Speakers and Headphones.

MUS 435.course_description: The course will cover the use of large-scale systems for the purpose of live sound reproduction. Everything from designing the setup, to loading the truck, to troubleshooting and budget creation will be included.

MUS 439.course_description: This course will look at the complete, modern recording session in detail, including mic placement and selection, effects processing, proper sound production, running a session, artist communication, and more.

MUS 444.course_name: Entertainment and Fine Arts Law I

MUS 445.course_name: Entertainment and Fine Arts Law II

MUS 446.course_description: Study of composition and formation for competitive Marching Drumline. Designed for marching band and marching percussion instructors. Includes classroom instruction and three hours practicum.

MUS 451.course_name: Ensemble Methods for Jazz and Commercial Music
MUS 451.course_description: Study and implementation of pedagogical techniques as they relate to the rehearsal and preparation of jazz and commercial music.

MUS 453.course_description: Development of music skills useful in teaching and integrating music in the elementary grades. Classroom and performance projects on recorder, Orff instruments and classroom percussion instruments. Methods, materials, and techniques of Jaques-Dalcroze, Orff-Schulwerk, and Kodaly studied for functional application.

MUS 455*.course_description: Techniques for teaching and integrating music for exceptional children.

MUS 457.course_name: Jazz and Commercial Music Keyboard Seminar
MUS 457.course_description: Continuation of MUS 257 with emphasis on advanced techniques and a free exchange of ideas and concepts. May be repeated to a maximum of six credits.

MUS 459.course_name: Advanced Jazz and Commercial Arranging and Composition
MUS 459.course_description: Continuation of MUS 359, with emphasis on more advanced contemporary styles of jazz and commercial writing including the usage of variable time signatures and new harmonic possibilities.

MUS 460.course_description: Course will include guidance, private study and projects tailored to the student’s needs to complete a successful course of study in Music Technology fields. Student will complete a project to include topics studied in the minor area of their degree plan and be integrated into their Music Technology Capstone project.

MUS 465.course_description: Emphasis on techniques of orchestration for the full symphony orchestra. Analysis of symphonic scores from all periods.

MUS 469.course_description: Learn techniques associated with the art of playing world percussion. Specific ethnic instruments from the Middle East, Far East, Africa and South America are studied in context of historical, social and performance practices.

MUS 470.course_description: Supervised group and individual lesson teaching experience for bassoon, oboe, and horn majors or minors as part of the Endangered Instrument Project. Field experience weekly at one of nine Clark County “at-risk” middle schools and one seminar during the first week of class. Fulfills instrumental pedagogy requirement.

MUS 480.course_description: Auditory, vocal, mental and neuromusculoskeletal health will be studied, focusing on health preservation and injury prevention among musicians, including performance anxiety issues. Students will learn relevant anatomy and physiology, as well as the ergonomics of music. Somatic disciplines such as Body Mapping, Yoga, or Alexander Technique may also be explored.

MUS 481E.course_description: Enrolled in a degree-seeking program; minimum 2.75 cumulative GPA, fingerprinting; passing PPST scores.

MUS 482.course_description: Music education teacher candidates attend required seminar sessions during student teaching. The seminar is designed to provide support for correlating professional education courses to actual classroom teaching experiences, reflective opportunities for self-assessment and systematic connections between university and school district supervisory personnel.

MUS 490.course_description: Supervised projects in the music business, including forming, recording, promoting and performing with one’s own band, website creation, product marketing, and music licensing.

MUS 491.course_description: Study of topics in music history and literature. Topic to vary by semester.

MUS 492.course_description: Study of topics in ethnomusicology and global music. Topics to vary by semester.

MUS 493.course_description: Explores a specific aspect of the study of music. May sometimes meet with HON 420.

MUS 495.course_description: Open to junior and senior students majoring in music. Students must present proposals, including names of advisors and number of credits, no later than one week before registration. a) History/Literature b) Theory/Composition c) Music Education.

MUS 499.course_description: Presentation of a full recital (minimum of 40 minutes actual playing time).
